thread.title: Fiorina aide takes jab at Trump, Carson for demanding shorter debate
thread.title_full: Fiorina aide takes jab at Trump, Carson for demanding shorter debate | Washington Examiner

author: Gabby Morrongiello
title: Fiorina aide takes jab at Trump, Carson for demanding shorter debate
text:
Two presidential hopefuls topping the Republican field, Donald Trump and Ben Carson, announced Thursday in a joint letter to CNBC they will not be participating in the third GOP debate if it is exceeds two hours and excludes opening and closing statements.
The outsider duo, first and second in the Washington Examiner power rankings , cited concerns that the second debate's three-hour length was too long and said personal statements serve to ensure each candidate has a chance to be heard.
But a top aide to one of Carson and Trump's rivals said perhaps there's a different reason they're calling for a time limit.
Related Story: http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/article/2574118/ Seems @JebBush isn't only low energy guy! Looks like @realDonaldTrump @RealBenCarson don't have endurance to debate @CarlyFiorina for 3hrs.— Sarah Isgur Flores (@whignewtons) October 15, 2015 
  Bush and Rubio squabble while Trump runs away with it After Bush announced his fundraising total, his campaign started a spat with Rubio over who did better.
By Byron York • 10/16/15 6:19 AM Sarah Isgur Flores, deputy campaign manager to Carly Fiorina, suggested the two candidates might be avoiding a prolonged on-stage competition with Fiorina.
@GideonResnick I'm all for more questions and fewer canned "politician" statements.— Sarah Isgur Flores (@whignewtons) October 15, 2015 
Asked by a reporter what she made of Carson and Trump's request for closing statements, Isgur Flores said she would prefer to see the candidates field additional questions.
In an earlier statement to the Washington Examiner , CNBC spokesman Brian Steel said the network plans to host "the most substantive debate possible," but would take Trump and Carson's suggestions into consideration.
Also from the Washington Examiner Boehner's bucket list: Find a speaker, solve fiscal train wreck The current House speaker had hoped he could retire on Oct. 30.
By Susan Ferrechio • 10/16/15 12:01 AM Top Story RNC chair: Republicans are 'cooked' if defeated in 2016 The Republican Party has become a "a midterm party" that struggles with the presidential elections.
By Al Weaver • 10/16/15 12:01 AM
